I actually used some of this ultracold science to come up with a method of FTL travel for my scifi story. Basically, they have a metamaterial that treats anything encapsulated in it as a Bose-Einstein condensate, regardless of the temperature of the encapsulated object. Pump that nanokelvin-temp metamaterial into a force field around a ship, then the ship's guidance system can make adjustments to the probability waveform, which, when collapsed again, essentially teleports the ship across space, kinda like the Heart of Gold from The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy. The colder the metamaterial in the force field, the farther the ship can go in a single jump.

https://youtu.be/CUjt36SD3h8 This video explains as to why light slows when traveling through a medium. The electromagnetic field (EMF) of the light wave interacts with the EMF of the electron and causes it to oscillate. As electrons obide by wave-particle duality it is essentially creating an oscillating wave that is travelling slower than the light wave and the two waves superimpose. I came up with a spaceship propulsion method for a scifi story I'm writing that uses this sort of stuff. Basically, this alien race has come up with a metamaterial that treats anything it encapsulates as a Bose-Einstein condensate regardless of the temperature of the encapsulated object (the metamaterial still has to be 2 nanokelvin or colder). So you set up a field of this ultracold stuff around the ship, turning the entire mass into a single quantum entity. If it's one quantum entity, it has one quantum wavelength, and the ship's guidance system manipulates that wavelength, changing the probability that it will be in a specific spot. This essentially makes the ship teleport itself light-years away. Do several jumps in quick succession, and you can travel hundreds of light-years in a matter of minutes.

I think the statement "the coldest particles are; the less they move. It's actually the other way around. The slower particles move; the "colder" something becomes. So what about lasertraps like the ones at the ILP in Hamburg?
They shoot Lasers from all sides in a frequency (and create a vacuum inside the box) so that the atoms cant move (well almost). One of those traps can trap just 1 atom and another one brings a couple thousand in to the Bose-Einstein-Kondensat state.
I've had a Tour there, and it's just incredible how finetuned the lasers have to be and all the mirrors and lenses, to get to just the right frequency to then make a 'photos' in that nanosecond, to study the behavior of said atoms.
